questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of left groin pain for 1 month. The pain radiates to his left knee and is aggravated on walking. He fell during soccer practice 5 weeks ago but did not see a doctor about it and does not recall any immediate and persistent pain after the event. He has hypothyroidism. His only medication is levothyroxine. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears uncomfortable. He is at the 50th percentile for height and at the 95th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 77/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. The patient has a left-sided, antalgic gait. The left lower extremity is externally rotated. The left hip is tender to palpation and internal rotation is limited by pain. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
9,100/mm3



Platelet count
250,000/mm3



Serum



 TSH
3.6 μU/mL


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Septic arthritis of the left hip
Developmental dysplasia of the left hip

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease would also cause antalgic gait with groin pain that is aggravated by walking and impaired internal rotation of the affected hip. However, this patient's age makes this diagnosis unlikely, as this condition is most common in children between 4–10 years of age. Furthermore, this condition tends to have a slower and more gradual symptom onset.

B) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has manifestations consistent with septic arthritis, such as joint pain and reduced range of motion, he is missing several key findings, such as fever, joint swelling, and abnormal lab values (e.g., increased ESR).

C) CORRECT:

The cause of slipped capital femoral epiphysis is not fully understood, but it occurs most often in obese children between 10–16 years of age. There also appears to be an association with endocrine disorders, such as hypothyroidism. Hip pain and an externally rotated thigh (internal rotation is very painful) are typical of this condition. The next step would be to confirm the diagnosis through an x-ray of the left hip. Surgical pinning of the femoral head is indicated for both stable and unstable slipped capital femoral epiphysis.

See “Common causes of hip pain in children” table.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has some features consistent with osteomyelitis, such as groin pain that aggravates with walking and reduced range of motion. However, osteomyelitis is extremely unlikely because he is missing key findings such as malaise, fever, chills, leukocytosis, and elevated inflammation markers (e.g., ESR).

E) INCORRECT:

Although transient synovitis can manifest with unilateral groin pain and antalgic gait, this patient has no history of viral infection, which usually precedes the onset of this condition. Moreover, his age makes the disorder unlikely, as transient synovitis most commonly affects children 3–8 years of age.

F) INCORRECT:

Developmental dysplasia of the hip is an unlikely diagnosis in this patient because it is most frequently seen in girls and usually becomes symptomatic in the first year of life. Additionally, at this age, this condition would have caused a discrepancy in leg length, unless it was bilateral, in which case it would manifest with a waddling gait and hyperlordosis, none of which is seen in this patient.
questions.hint: An x-ray of this patient's left hip would show widening of the joint space and a femoral head that is displaced posteriorly and inferiorly in relation to the femoral neck.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a limp for the last 3 weeks. He has also had right hip pain during this period. The pain is aggravated when he runs. He had a runny nose and fever around a month ago that resolved with over-the-counter medications. He has no history of serious illness. His development is adequate for his age. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears healthy. He is at the 60th percentile for height and at 65th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an antalgic gait. The right groin is tender to palpation. Internal rotation and abduction of the right hip is limited by pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8,900/mm3, and platelet count is 170,000/mm3. An x-ray of the pelvis is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of the femoral head

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An unstable proximal femoral growth plate is the underlying cause of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE). A hip x-ray would show a widened femoral epiphyseal plate with increased lucency, and/or femoral head posteroinferior displacement in relation to the femoral neck. Additionally, SCFE most commonly affects obese males between 10–16 years of age, making a diagnosis of SCFE in this 7-year-old patient unlikely.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis ( AP view) of a 14-year-old boy

Widening of the right femoral growth plate (physis; blue overlay) is accompanied by inferior and medial displacement of the epiphysis (green overlay) on the femoral neck (red overlay), which is cranially positioned relative to the acetabulum. Widening of the right hip joint is also seen (indicated by double-arrows). The left femur is also abnormal, with a widened neck. A line (Klein line; dashed lines) along the lateral edge of the superior femoral neck on either side does not intersect the respective epiphysis.

GS: gonad shield

B) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis is caused by bacterial infection of a joint, and manifests with joint pain and a restricted range of motion. However, patients with septic arthritis usually have fever, an elevated leukocyte count, and a more acute disease course than seen in this patient. Additionally, septic arthritis is typically more painful than Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease. While this child has a limp and pain while running, a patient with septic arthritis of the hip would typically avoid bearing weight on the affected side because of pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Transient synovitis of the hip may occur following a viral process such as an upper respiratory tract infection. The pain from transient synovitis of the hip usually resolves within approx. 7 days and is unlikely to persist for 3 weeks. Moreover, unlike this child, patients with transient synovitis often have normal x-ray findings; ultrasound or MRI of the hip may show joint effusions in some patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is associated with immune-mediated synovial inflammation. Hip involvement occurs in 35–60% of patients with JIA and may manifest with hip pain and a limp that is characteristically worse early in the morning and improves with activity during the day. In this child, however, the pain is exacerbated by running. In addition, hip x-ray findings in the early stage of JIA are usually normal. Most importantly, this patient has had symptoms for about 3 weeks, and a diagnosis of JIA cannot be considered unless symptoms are present for more than 6 weeks.

E) CORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease is characterized by necrosis of the femoral head due to poor vascular perfusion, which leads to hip pain and decreased ability to bear weight in the affected hip joint, as well as x-ray findings of joint space widening and femoral head flattening. The underlying pathophysiology is multifactorial, poorly understood, and often described as idiopathic avascular necrosis. Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease likely results from a combination of repetitive mechanical stress, microtrauma, and genetic predisposition. This patient should be treated nonsurgically with NSAIDs, physical therapy, and restriction of weight-bearing. Surgical treatment should be considered for children with extensive damage to the femoral head.

See “Common causes of hip pain in children” table.
Image Description:

A. Normal anatomy: The femoral head is located in the center of the acetabulum.
B. Femoral head necrosis leads to lateral subluxation and displacement of the femoral head in the acetabulum.
C. Fractures and subsequent bone resorption result in an unstable femoral head. Lateral displacement puts a pathological strain on the femoral head when weight-bearing, which leads to deformities.
D. Hinge abduction: On hip abduction, the deformed lateral pillar of the femoral head impinges on the acetabular rim, preventing the femoral head from entering the acetabulum. This results in a hinge joint articulation instead of a ball-and-socket joint articulation at the hip.
questions.hint: Hip pain with limited internal rotation and abduction in addition to x-ray findings of joint space widening and femoral head flattening are consistent with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, which most commonly affects boys aged 4–10 years.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of right hip pain that started that afternoon. His mother reports that he has also been limping since the pain developed. He says that the pain worsens when he moves or walks. He participated in a dance recital yesterday, but his mother believes that he was not injured at the time. He was born at term and has been healthy except for an episode of nasal congestion and mild cough 10 days ago. His mother has rheumatoid arthritis and his grandmother has osteoporosis. He is at the 50th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 90/78 mm Hg. His right hip is slightly abducted and externally rotated. Examination shows no tenderness, warmth, or erythema. He is able to bear weight. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 12.3 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 8500/mm3, and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 12 mm/h. Ultrasonography of the right hip shows increased fluid within the joint. X-ray of the hips shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) are typically older than this patient, presenting at about 10–16 years of age. Additionally, SCFE occurs most often in obese boys, and this patient is at the 50th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. Exam findings would also likely reveal external rotation along with flexion at the hip, not just external rotation and abduction. X-ray would show sclerotic epiphysis with joint widening when radiographic changes begin, but might be normal for the initial 4–6 months, meaning imaging alone is not enough to exclude SCFE in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

This otherwise healthy child presents with a recent history of upper respiratory tract infection as well as hip pain and a limp for the past 24 hours, the combination of which suggests transient synovitis (TS). On exam, the right hip is slightly abducted and externally rotated, a common finding in patients with hip pain as this position decreases joint capsule tension and the resulting pain. Patients with TS typically present with no (or low-grade) fever and normal laboratory findings (e.g., normal WBC count and ESR). TS can manifest with unilateral or bilateral joint effusion on ultrasonography, unlike septic arthritis, in which joint effusion is almost always a unilateral finding.

TS is a mild, self-limited disease and treatment is conservative with NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) and rest. If the effusion and/or the hip pain fails to resolve, follow-up imaging should be obtained to reassess for other conditions (e.g., Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease).

C) INCORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD) is commonly seen in young patients who present with insidious-onset hip pain that may fluctuate with activity and a limp. X-ray findings may be normal in early disease and in later disease show medial joint space widening and an area of radiolucency around the femoral head indicative of subchondral fracture (crescent sign). While early LCPD cannot be entirely excluded, the patient's recent upper respiratory tract infection and the acute onset of symptoms make another diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis (AP view) of a child

The left femoral epiphysis (green overlay) is small, flattened (coxa plana), and sclerotic. The hip joint space is widened.

This appearance is consistent with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease. Early radiographic findings may include medial joint space widening and reduced bone density. Later, the femoral head may become small, fragmented, flattened, and sclerotic.

D) INCORRECT:

Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) is usually detected in newborns. Risk factors are female sex, breech delivery, and a family history of DDH. If not identified at birth, DDH can lead to progressive hip pain and difficulty walking very early in life. This patient has a normal birth history and has not had hip pain until this point. Moreover, unlike in this patient, an x-ray of a patient with DDH would likely be abnormal, with potential findings of acetabular dysplasia or femoral head dysplasia.
Image Description:

Pelvis and hips (AP view) of a 3 month old infant

Hilgenreiner’s line has been drawn horizontally connecting the inferior aspect of the ilium through the triradiate cartilages. The femoral heads should be below this line. The acetabular angle is measured between Hilgenreiner’s line and a line parallel to the acetabular roof.

The acetabular angle (or acetabular index) should be < 28 degrees at birth and should progressively decrease with hip maturation. At 3 months old, the normal acetabular angle is typically reported as in the range of 25 degrees, with a maximum measurement of 30 degrees. The acetabular angle in this patient is >30 degrees.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has a recent infection, making him susceptible to septic arthritis of the hip. However, the index of suspicion for septic arthritis should be low in this case because the patient is able to bear weight and has normal vital signs and laboratory studies. Furthermore, a patient with septic arthritis of the hip would present with exquisite hip pain on palpation and the skin over the affected joint would be warm and erythematous.

F) INCORRECT:

Although osteomyelitis of the hip or femur can manifest with pain and limping, the affected area is typically tender and warm to palpation. In children, osteomyelitis also usually affects the long-bone metaphysis rather than the joints, which would be more likely affected in infants. Laboratory findings usually include an elevated WBC count and ESR. X-ray often shows no abnormalities during the first few days of infection but may reveal periosteal bone deposition.
questions.hint: This patient's effusion will likely improve over the next couple of weeks.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 2-week history of right hip pain. His mother reports that he has been limping because the pain is aggravated by walking. The pain radiates to the right knee. He has not had any fever, cough, or a runny nose. He is otherwise healthy and has reached all developmental milestones for his age. Physical examination shows a restricted range of internal rotation as well as pain on flexion and abduction of the right hip. He has a right-sided antalgic gait. Hemoglobin concentration is 13.7 g/dL, leukocyte count is 7,900/mm3, and platelet count is 185,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Developmental dysplasia of the hip is characterized by abnormal development of the acetabulum, which results in hip instability, hip pain, and a restricted range of abduction. However, this condition typically becomes symptomatic in the first year of life. Late findings, which can be seen in children ∼ 18 months of age, include leg length discrepancy and a waddling or a Trendelenburg gait.

B) INCORRECT:

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is characterized by immune-mediated synovial inflammation and can involve the hip, which results in pain. However, pain associated with JIA is characteristically worse early in the morning and improves with activity during the day. This patient's pain is exacerbated by walking. In addition, JIA is typically associated with intermittent fever and elevated inflammatory markers, including leukocyte count.

C) INCORRECT:

Transient synovitis is characterized by inflammation of the hip joint capsule and is a common cause of acute hip pain among children (peak incidence of 3–8 years of age). However, this condition is typically associated with a recent viral infection. This patient has no evidence of current or recent infection (no fever, cough, runny nose, or leukocytosis). In addition, symptoms of transient synovitis generally improve within 24 hours and resolve within 2 weeks.

D) INCORRECT:

Osgood-Schlatter disease is characterized primarily by anterior knee pain due to repetitive strain (overuse of the quadriceps muscle) during periods of growth. It is not associated with hip pain or a restricted range of motion of the hip joint. In addition, it more commonly affects older boys (peak incidence of 9–14 years of age).

E) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis is caused by bacterial infection of a joint and typically manifests with joint pain and restricted range of motion. However, patients with septic arthritis usually have fever, leukocytosis, and a more acute disease course. In addition, although this patient does have an antalgic gait, septic arthritis of the hip joint typically results in severe pain that impairs weight bearing.

F) INCORRECT:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is characterized by posterior and inferior displacement of the femoral epiphysis and can manifest with hip pain, referred knee pain, a restricted range of internal rotation of the hip, and an antalgic gait. Although acute presentations of SCFE (which are associated with < 3 weeks of symptoms) can occur, they are usually associated with trauma. Most presentations of SCFE are chronic and manifest with vague, intermittent symptoms across several weeks to months. Moreover, SCFE is most commonly seen in obese children who are 10–16 years of age.

G) CORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD) is characterized by avascular necrosis of the femoral head and is due to rapid epiphyseal growth without adequate blood supply. LCPD most commonly manifests in boys 4–10 years of age with limping (due to a restricted range of internal rotation and abduction of the hip), and pain of the hip on flexion, abduction, and external rotation, sometimes projecting to the knee. This condition typically has an insidious onset and is not associated with fever or hematologic abnormalities. Its underlying pathophysiology is not fully understood, but it is likely multifactorial, arising from a combination of repetitive mechanical stress, microtrauma, and genetic predisposition.

See “Common causes of hip pain in children” table.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis (AP view)

Both femoral epiphyses show flattening (blue lines) and sclerosis with areas of fragmentation (examples indicated by arrows).

The appearance is consistent with avascular necrosis of the capital femoral epiphyses of the femoral heads.
questions.hint: Patients with this condition may have unremarkable pelvic radiographs in the first 3–6 months after onset. Early changes include joint space widening, sclerosis of the femoral head, and disparate femoral head sizes.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old woman with a long history of alcohol and tobacco use reports 3 months of worsening pain in her left hip, groin, and buttock. The pain is exacerbated by weight-bearing activity and relieved with rest. She denies any recent falls or trauma.
On examination, she has diminished hip abduction and pain with passive external and internal rotation. Active hip flexion causes minimal pain. She has no tenderness along the lateral aspect of the hip.
A hip radiograph 6 weeks ago was reported as showing only features of mild osteoarthritis.
What is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with hip flexor strain would feel acute pain while running or twisting and also with active or resisted hip flexion. Passive hip range of motion is typically well preserved.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with hip fractures and dislocations present acutely in severe pain and have a reduced range of motion.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with hip fractures and dislocations present acutely in severe pain and have a reduced range of motion.

D) CORRECT:

Most cases of osteonecrosis (avascular necrosis) are nontraumatic, with the majority caused by chronic glucocorticoid therapy or excessive alcohol use. Radiation therapy, chemotherapy, coagulopathies, hypercoagulable states, and cigarette smoking are also significant risk factors. The most common causes of traumatic hip osteonecrosis are hip dislocations and subluxations.

Patients with osteonecrosis of the femoral head typically present with hip pain that is exacerbated by weight-bearing activity and relieved with rest. The pain typically extends to the groin and may also radiate to the buttock, knee, or greater trochanter. Patients typically have diminished hip abduction and pain with passive external and internal rotation. Radiographs initially show subchondral sclerosis with femoral head lucency, which may eventually progress to joint space narrowing, acetabular changes, and flattening of the femoral head.

Osteonecrosis is often bilateral, even in patients with unilateral symptoms, so it is prudent to obtain bilateral plain radiographs. MRI may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis if initial radiographs are normal and suspicion is high.

Key learning point: Osteonecrosis of the femoral head classically manifests with groin pain exacerbated by weight-bearing activity, diminished hip abduction, and pain with passive external and internal rotation.

E) INCORRECT:

Greater trochanteric pain syndrome (formerly referred to as trochanteric bursitis) is typically caused by chronic overuse of the hip and by gluteal muscle weakness. Pain is felt laterally along the greater trochanter and sometimes radiates along the iliotibial band. Pain does not localize to the groin, and the presence of such a symptom should prompt further investigation for other etiologies.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the office because of a 2-week history of right hip pain. His mother reports that he has been limping because the pain is aggravated by walking. The pain radiates to the right knee. He has not had any fever, cough, or a runny nose. Physical examination shows a restricted range of internal rotation as well as pain on flexion and abduction of the right hip. He has a right-sided antalgic gait. Hemoglobin concentration is 13.7 g/dL, leukocyte count is 7,900/mm3, and platelet count is 185,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Developmental dysplasia of the hip is characterized by abnormal development of the acetabulum, which results in hip instability, hip pain, and a restricted range of abduction. However, this condition typically becomes symptomatic in the first year of life. Late findings, which can be seen in children ∼ 18 months of age, include leg length discrepancy and a waddling or a Trendelenburg gait.

B) INCORRECT:

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is characterized by immune-mediated synovial inflammation and can involve the hip, which results in pain. However, pain associated with JIA is characteristically worse early in the morning and improves with activity during the day. This patient's pain is exacerbated by walking. In addition, JIA is typically associated with intermittent fever and elevated inflammatory markers, including leukocyte count.

C) INCORRECT:

Transient synovitis is characterized by inflammation of the hip joint capsule and is a common cause of acute hip pain among children (peak incidence of 3–8 years of age). However, this condition is typically associated with a recent viral infection. This patient has no evidence of current or recent infection (no fever, cough, runny nose, or leukocytosis). In addition, symptoms of transient synovitis generally improve within 24 hours and resolve within 2 weeks.

D) INCORRECT:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is characterized by posterior and inferior displacement of the femoral epiphysis and can manifest with hip pain, referred knee pain, a restricted range of internal rotation of the hip, and an antalgic gait. Although acute presentations of SCFE (which are associated with < 3 weeks of symptoms) can occur, they are usually associated with trauma. Most presentations of SCFE are chronic and manifest with vague, intermittent symptoms across several weeks to months. Moreover, SCFE is most commonly seen in obese children who are 10–16 years of age.

E) CORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD) is characterized by avascular necrosis of the femoral head and is due to rapid epiphyseal growth without adequate blood supply. LCPD most commonly manifests in boys 4–10 years of age with limping (due to a restricted range of internal rotation and abduction of the hip), and pain of the hip on flexion, abduction, and external rotation, sometimes projecting to the knee. This condition typically has an insidious onset and is not associated with fever or hematologic abnormalities. Its underlying pathophysiology is not fully understood, but it is likely multifactorial, arising from a combination of repetitive mechanical stress, microtrauma, and genetic predisposition.

See “Common causes of hip pain in children” table.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis (AP view)

Both femoral epiphyses show flattening (blue lines) and sclerosis with areas of fragmentation (examples indicated by arrows).

The appearance is consistent with avascular necrosis of the capital femoral epiphyses of the femoral heads.
questions.hint: Patients with this condition may have unremarkable pelvic radiographs in the first 3–6 months after onset. Early changes include joint space widening, sclerosis of the femoral head, and disparate femoral head sizes.

Furthermore, this condition tends to have a slower and more gradual symptom onset.

This patient has some features consistent with osteomyelitis, such as groin pain that aggravates with walking and reduced range of motion. questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to your clinic by his mother because of a 2-week history of right hip pain. His mother reports that he has been limping, and the pain worsens with walking. The pain radiates to his right knee. He has not had fever, cough, or runny nose. On examination, there is restricted internal rotation and pain with flexion and abduction of the right hip. He has a right-sided antalgic gait. Laboratory studies show: hemoglobin 137 g/L (115–155), white blood cell count 7.9 × 109/L (3.5–10.5), and platelet count 185 × 109/L (130–380). Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is characterized by posterior and inferior displacement of the femoral epiphysis and can manifest with hip pain, referred knee pain, a restricted range of internal rotation of the hip, and an antalgic gait. Although acute presentations of SCFE (which are associated with < 3 weeks of symptoms) can occur, they are usually associated with trauma. Most presentations of SCFE are chronic and manifest with vague, intermittent symptoms across several weeks to months. Moreover, SCFE is most commonly seen in obese children who are 10–16 years of age.

B) CORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD) is characterized by avascular necrosis of the femoral head and is due to rapid epiphyseal growth without adequate blood supply. LCPD most commonly manifests in boys 4–10 years of age with limping (due to a restricted range of internal rotation and abduction of the hip), and pain of the hip and/or upper leg, sometimes referred to the knee, often exacerbated by internal rotation. This condition typically has an insidious onset and is not associated with fever or hematologic abnormalities. Its underlying pathophysiology is not fully understood, but it is likely multifactorial, arising from a combination of repetitive mechanical stress, microtrauma, and genetic predisposition.

See "Differential diagnosis of pediatric hip pain" table.

Key learning point: Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease is avascular necrosis of the femoral head in children aged 4–10, presenting with insidious hip pain, limp, and restricted hip motion without systemic symptoms or laboratory abnormalities.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis (AP view)

Both femoral epiphyses show flattening (blue lines) and sclerosis with areas of fragmentation (examples indicated by arrows).

The appearance is consistent with avascular necrosis of the capital femoral epiphyses of the femoral heads.

C) INCORRECT:

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is characterized by immune-mediated synovial inflammation and can involve the hip, which results in pain. However, pain associated with JIA is characteristically worse early in the morning and improves with activity during the day. This patient's pain is exacerbated by walking. In addition, JIA is typically associated with intermittent fever and elevated inflammatory markers, including leukocyte count.

Transient synovitis is characterized by inflammation of the hip joint capsule and is a common cause of acute hip pain among children (peak incidence of 3–8 years of age). However, this condition is typically associated with a recent viral infection. This patient has no evidence of current or recent infection (no fever, cough, runny nose, or leukocytosis). In addition, symptoms of transient synovitis generally improve within 24 hours and resolve within 2 weeks.

E) INCORRECT:

Developmental dysplasia of the hip is characterized by abnormal development of the acetabulum, which results in hip instability, hip pain, and a restricted range of abduction. However, this condition typically becomes symptomatic in the first year of life. Late findings, which can be seen in children ∼ 18 months of age, include leg length discrepancy and a waddling or a Trendelenburg gait.
questions.hint: Patients with this condition may have unremarkable pelvic radiographs in the first 3–6 months after onset. Early changes include joint space widening, sclerosis of the femoral head, and disparate femoral head sizes.

He reports falling during soccer practice 5 weeks ago but did not seek medical attention at that time and does not recall any immediate or persistent pain after the fall. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.1°C, pulse is 77/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. He has a left-sided antalgic gait, and his left lower extremity is externally rotated. The left hip is tender to palpation, and internal rotation is limited by pain. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Developmental dysplasia of the left hip.

A) INCORRECT:

Although transient synovitis can manifest with unilateral groin pain and antalgic gait, this patient has no history of viral infection, which usually precedes the onset of this condition. Moreover, his age makes the disorder unlikely, as transient synovitis most commonly affects children 3–8 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has some features consistent with osteomyelitis, such as groin pain that aggravates with walking and reduced range of motion. However, osteomyelitis is extremely unlikely because he is missing key findings such as malaise, fever, chills, leukocytosis, and elevated inflammation markers (e.g., ESR).

C) INCORRECT:

Developmental dysplasia of the hip is an unlikely diagnosis in this patient because it is most frequently seen in girls and usually becomes symptomatic in the first year of life. Additionally, at this age, this condition would have caused a discrepancy in leg length, unless it was bilateral, in which case it would manifest with a waddling gait and hyperlordosis, none of which is seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

The cause of slipped capital femoral epiphysis is not fully understood, but it occurs most often in obese children between 10–16 years of age. There also appears to be an association with endocrine disorders, such as hypothyroidism. Hip pain and an externally rotated thigh (internal rotation is very painful) are typical of this condition. The next step would be to confirm the diagnosis through an x-ray of the left hip. Surgical pinning of the femoral head is indicated for both stable and unstable slipped capital femoral epiphysis.

See “Common causes of hip pain in children” table.

Key learning point: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis typically presents in adolescents with hip or knee pain, an antalgic gait, and an externally rotated, painful hip with limited internal rotation.

E) INCORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease would also cause antalgic gait with groin pain that is aggravated by walking and impaired internal rotation of the affected hip. However, this patient's age makes this diagnosis unlikely, as this condition is most common in children between 4–10 years of age. Furthermore, this condition tends to have a slower and more gradual symptom onset.
questions.hint: An x-ray of this patient's left hip would show widening of the joint space and a femoral head that is displaced posteriorly and inferiorly in relation to the femoral neck.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a 2-day history of left hip pain and limping. His mother reports he had a cold last week but has had no fever. Vital signs are P, 105; T, 38.3°C (101.0°F). He walks with an antalgic gait and holds his left hip in slight flexion and external rotation. Range of motion testing shows pain with internal rotation and abduction. Laboratory studies show WBC 14,000/mm3, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 45 mm/hr, and C-reactive protein (CRP) 25 mg/L. Which of the following management steps should be prioritized?

choices.text: MRI of the hip to rule out osteomyelitis
Obtain hip ultrasound to assess for effusion
Administer ibuprofen and discharge with orthopedic follow-up
Obtain blood cultures and start empiric antibiotics

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- The combination of fever, elevated inflammatory markers (ESR > 40 mm/hr, CRP > 20 mg/L), and clinical features of hip pain with limited range of motion in a child strongly suggests septic arthritis. The most critical priority is urgent orthopedic consultation and arthrocentesis, as delays can increase the risk for joint destruction and long-term complications.

B) INCORRECT:

MRI would unnecessarily delay definitive diagnosis and treatment. While MRI may be performed later if osteomyelitis is suspected, the immediate priority is arthrocentesis to evaluate for septic arthritis, which is a surgical emergency requiring prompt intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

While ultrasound can identify joint effusion, it would not alter management in this clinical scenario. The combination of fever, elevated inflammatory markers, and clinical presentation requires immediate arthrocentesis regardless of ultrasound findings.

D) INCORRECT:

Conservative management would be an appropriate treatment for transient synovitis, which also manifests with joint pain. However, this patient's presentation is more consistent with septic arthritis, which requires urgent evaluation.

E) INCORRECT:

While blood cultures may be obtained, starting empiric antibiotics is not the priority. Arthrocentesis should be performed urgently to obtain synovial fluid for analysis and culture, which is the gold standard for diagnosis of septic arthritis.
